Introduction

Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) encompass all mycobacterial species outside the Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium leprae complexes.  Unlike M tuberculosis and M leprae, NTM are environmental organisms, ubiquitous in soil and water, with no obligate requirement for human hosts.  The most clinically significant species is the Mycobacterium avium complex, a major cause of chronic pulmonary infection.  In some countries (eg, the United States), the prevalence of pulmonary NTM disease surpasses that of tuberculosis in many regions, particularly among older adults and those with chronic lung disease.

Classification



Mycobacteria are divided into 3 large complexes:



  • M tuberculosis complex includes M tuberculosis, Mycobacterium bovis, Mycobacterium africanum, and other closely related species.  They require a human (or animal) host and are the cause of tuberculosis (TB).
  • M leprae (and its close relative Mycobacterium lepromatosis) also require a human or animal host and can cause leprosy (Hansen disease).
  • NTM are ubiquitous in the environment and do not require a host for survival.  They typically cause opportunistic infections in individuals with underlying lung disease (eg, bronchiectasis) or immunodeficiency (eg, HIV).  NTM are classified as:
    • Slow growers (colonies visible after 7 days), which include M avium-intracellulare complex (MAI or MAC), Mycobacterium kansasii, and Mycobacterium marinum.
    • Rapid growers (colonies visible within 7 days), which include Mycobacterium abscessus, Mycobacterium fortuitum, and Mycobacterium chelonae.


This article focuses mainly on MAI/MAC, a slow-growing environmental mycobacterium that is the leading cause of human NTM disease.

Pathophysiology

Microbiology



NTM have an acid-fast, lipid-rich cell wall that appears identical to that of M tuberculosis, but they are generally less virulent.  Their virulence factors include surface glycolipids (eg, lipoarabinomannan, glycopeptidolipids [GPLs], phosphatidylinositol mannosides) that mask antigens, promote biofilm formation, and disrupt phagosome-lysosome fusion.

Transmission



NTM are acquired directly from the environment, unlike M tuberculosis and M leprae, which are obligate pathogens transmitted between other infected humans or animals.  NTM reservoirs include soil (particularly in damp climates) and household or municipal water sources (eg, tap water, hot tubs, plumbing, biofilms).



Infection can occur through:



  • Inhalation of aerosols (most common route), which leads mainly to pulmonary disease.
  • Ingestion (less common), which can lead to disseminated disease in patients with severe immunodeficiency (eg, decreased gut T cells).
  • Direct inoculation, which can produce skin and soft tissue infections (eg, cervical lymphadenitis, draining abscesses) typically caused by rapidly growing NTM (eg, M abscessus).

Pathogenesis



When NTM are inhaled, most are engulfed quickly by alveolar macrophages.  Most of the bacilli are immediately destroyed by phagosome-lysosome fusion.  However, NTM can block phagolysosomal fusion (eg, via GPLs), surviving and slowly replicating within macrophages.  In most persons, this produces asymptomatic colonization.  The immune system responds by releasing IL-12 (a cytokine that is relatively specific to NTM), driving Th1 differentiation and interferon-gamma (IFN-Î³) production, which enhances macrophage killing.



  • If this response is successful, the infection is completely cleared.
  • If clearance is incomplete, the host walls off bacilli in granulomas, consisting of fused macrophages surrounded by a rim of lymphocytes.  These granulomas may hold disease back for years, but bacilli may eventually erode and cause local inflammation, producing chronic pulmonary NTM disease (eg, nodules, bronchiectasis, fibrosis).
  • In severely immunocompromised patients, granuloma formation fails.  Bacilli replicate unchecked in macrophages, spill out extracellularly into the bloodstream, and seed multiple organs, producing disseminated MAC infection (eg, fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, cytopenias).

Risk factors



Although exposure to NTM is common, clinical disease develops in only a minority of individuals.  The main risk factors are:



  • Structural lung disease, which creates poorly draining areas that are not adequately cleared by alveolar macrophages.  Examples include chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bronchiectasis (eg, cystic fibrosis), and prior pulmonary TB with residual scarring or cavities.
  • Immunodeficiency, particularly of cell-mediated immunity (eg, T cells), such as with immunosuppressive drugs (eg, antiâ€“tumor necrosis factor-alpha [TNFÎ±] therapies), advanced HIV (eg, CD4 <50/mm3), or mendelian susceptibility to mycobacterial disease, which is due to mutations leading to congenital loss of IL-12 and IFN-Î³ signaling.
  • Demographic and host factors, particularly elderly women with lean body habitus or individuals with chest wall abnormalities (eg, Marfan syndrome, pectus excavatum) associated with impaired mucociliary clearance


NTM are present globally but are most prevalent in warm and humid regions (eg, coastal) in North America, East Asia, and Northern Europe.

Clinical presentation



NTM infections are highly variable and depend on the species, site of infection, and host immune status.  The 3 main manifestations are pulmonary disease, disseminated disease, and other localized infections.

Pulmonary NTM



Pulmonary NTM disease is the most common manifestation.  There are 2 main patterns (

):



  • Nodular/bronchiectatic disease is the most common form.  It classically occurs in thin, elderly, nonsmoking women with no prior structural lung disease (Lady Windermere syndrome, based on the name of a character in a play).  It typically affects the middle lung zones (right middle lobe and lingula) with tree-in-bud nodularity and bronchiectasis on CT scan (
    image 1
    ).  Symptoms develop insidiously, often after years of colonization, and typically present with chronic cough, sputum production, fatigue, low-grade fever, weight loss, and, sometimes, scant hemoptysis.  Sputum acid-fast bacilli (AFB) smears and cultures may be negative or only intermittently positive, reflecting the low bacillary load and variable shedding.
  • Fibrocavitary disease is more aggressive.  It mainly affects middle-aged or older men with a history of smoking and structural lung disease (eg, emphysema, prior TB).  It resembles reactivation TB with upper lobe cavitary lesions surrounded by inflammatory infiltrates (
    image 2
    ).  Like TB, the cavitary lesions can even be seen on plain chest x-ray.  Symptoms are more severe and involve chronic productive cough, potentially significant hemoptysis (eg, vascular erosion), fever, and weight loss.  Sputum AFB smears and cultures are frequently positive, which is consistent with the higher pathogen burden.  Untreated disease can lead to permanent scarring and loss of lung function.


Other respiratory patterns include irregular consolidations, scattered nodules, or ground-glass opacities (a hypersensitivity pneumonitisâ€“like reaction to NTM antigens, rather than true infection).

Disseminated NTM



Gastric fluid and the small bowel are normally colonized by a low level of MAC (from drinking water and food).  In immunocompetent individuals, the bacilli are controlled by mucosal barriers and cleared by macrophages in gut-associated lymphoid tissue.  Disseminated infection (DMAC) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
) represents intestinal translocation and mostly affects patients with profound cellular immunodeficiency, especially advanced HIV (eg, CD4 <50/mm3), and those receiving potent immunosuppression (especially anti-TNFÎ± biologics such as infliximab or adalimumab).  MAC spreads via mesenteric lymph nodes into the bloodstream, seeding the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and lymph nodes.



Manifestations of DMAC include prominent constitutional symptoms (prolonged fever, night sweats, weight loss, cachexia) and gastrointestinal symptoms (chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, bulky abdominal lymphadenopathy).  Hepatosplenomegaly and cytopenias are common due to reticuloendothelial and bone marrow infiltration.  Alkaline phosphatase and lactate dehydrogenase are often elevated due to high macrophage turnover in the liver and bone marrow.  Blood cultures are frequently positive for MAC, and the organism can also be isolated from lymph nodes and bone marrow (

image 3
).



DMAC was historically a component of "HIV chronic wasting disease," a cachectic catabolic state due to multiple opportunistic infections such as DMAC, cryptosporidiosis, and cytomegalovirus.  Without therapy, DMAC is progressive and ~100% fatal.  With HIV antiviral therapy (ART) and a multiantibiotic regimen, the prognosis is markedly improved.

Other slow-growing NTM



Beyond pulmonary and disseminated disease, certain slow-growing NTM can cause other specific infections:



  • MAC cervical lymphadenitis is the most common extrapulmonary NTM manifestation.  It occurs mainly in young children (age <5) and presents as chronic, firm, nontender, unilateral cervical lymph node enlargement.  The nodes may progress to fluctuance with overlying violaceous discoloration of the skin, eventually breaking down to form draining sinus tracts.  However, systemic symptoms are typically absent.  Biopsy demonstrates granulomatous inflammation with caseation and necrosis (
    image 4
    ).
  • M marinum is an NTM that colonizes fish and aquatic environments (eg, aquariums, seafood tanks).  Infection occurs when contaminated water enters breaches in the skin, resulting in subcutaneous nodular lesions (fish-tank granulomas), often starting in the hands and forearms.  The nodules may ulcerate and spread along lymphatic channels (
    image 5
    ).
  • M kansasii is genetically closest to the M tuberculosis complex.  It mainly causes pulmonary disease, which resembles reactivation TB (eg, productive cough,  hemoptysis, fever, weight loss) with upper lobe cavitation on imaging.  Disseminated disease can also occur in patients who are immunocompromised.  Like M tuberculosis, M kansasii is highly responsive to therapy (eg, rifampin + isoniazid + pyrazinamide + ethambutol).
  • M chimaera is a biofilm-forming, slow-growing mycobacterium linked to ongoing outbreaks of an indolent DMAC presentation following cardiac surgery.  It is transmitted through contaminated cardiopulmonary bypass circuits.  Symptoms (eg, fever, hepatosplenomegaly) can appear from months to years after surgery.

Rapid-growing NTM



Rapid-growing NTM (eg, M abscessus, M fortuitum, and M chelonae) typically cause localized, opportunistic infections related to direct inoculation and medical procedures.



  • M abscessus is aggressive and difficult to treat due to intrinsic multidrug resistance.  In patients with underlying lung disease (particularly cystic fibrosis with bronchiectasis), it causes progressive cavitary lesions, sometimes resulting in lung abscesses and empyemas.  Skin and soft tissue infections can occur (eg, cosmetic surgery, tattooing), presenting with painful nodules, cellulitis, or draining sinuses that do not clear with standard antibiotic therapy.  Nosocomial device infections (catheters, prosthetic joints, cardiac valves) can also occur.
  • M fortuitum and M chelonae are less virulent than M abscessus and are implicated mainly in traumatic wound infections, postsurgical infections (eg, breast implants, pacemaker pockets), and catheter-related bacteremia.  M chelonae can also cause mycobacterial keratitis or endophthalmitis after ocular surgery or inappropriate contact lens use.

Diagnosis

Criteria



The first step in diagnosing NTM is distinguishing true infection from asymptomatic colonization.  Because NTM are environmental organisms, they are frequently isolated from respiratory specimens (ie, "treat the patient, not the culture").  To make this distinction, the Infectious Disease Society of America diagnostic criteria for pulmonary NTM disease require both of the following (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
):



  • Compatible radiographic abnormalities (eg, nodular/bronchiectatic changes, cavities, or consolidations)
  • Microbiologic or histologic evidence (eg, â‰¥2 positive AFB sputum cultures, granulomatous inflammation on biopsy with positive AFB and tissue cultures).


Clinical symptoms of chronic lower respiratory infection (eg, chronic cough, sputum, weight loss) may be absent.



For disseminated disease (ie, DMAC), the diagnosis is made using a positive blood culture.  For extrapulmonary disease (eg, lymphadenitis), diagnosis is made using culture or PCR from biopsy or aspirated material.

NTM versus TB



Both NTM and M tuberculosis are AFB and therefore cannot be distinguished on smear alone.



  • A positive AFB smear is treated as TB (eg, respiratory isolation) unless proved otherwise.
  • Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for TB is performed.  A positive AFB but negative NAAT signals a presumptive diagnosis of NTM.
  • At the same time, the bacilli are cultured to allow for speciation and sensitivity testing.  Results of cultures may take several weeks (eg, for slow-growing NTM).

Differential diagnosis



The differential for pulmonary NTM includes:



  • Reactivation TB, which also presents with upper lobe fibrocavitary disease.
  • Fungal infections such as the endemic mycoses (eg, pulmonary histoplasmosis, blastomycosis, coccidioidomycosis) or chronic necrotizing aspergillosis, which can cause chronically enlarging nodules, cavities, and bronchiectasis.
  • Nocardiosis, a weak AFB that can also cause chronic cavitary pneumonia but is classically associated with brain abscess and skin dissemination.
  • Malignancy, especially squamous cell lung cancer, which can cavitate due to tumor necrosis.
  • Noninfectious granulomatous lung diseases (eg, sarcoidosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis), which often produce middle to upper lobe nodularity.
  • Other causes of bronchiectasis (eg, common variable immunodeficiency, primary ciliary dysmotility).

Management

Whom to treat



Many patients have relatively indolent NTM disease (eg, stable nodules, mild bronchiectasis), so antibiotic therapy is not always indicated.  Such patients can be monitored with close follow-up, serial imaging (eg, yearly CT scan), sputum culture, and pulmonary function testing (PFT).  Approximately 40% of patients with pulmonary NTM have stable disease and never require treatment.



Treatment is reserved for patients with clinically significant disease because the therapy is prolonged, difficult to tolerate, and not always curative.  The decision is individualized.  Generally, treatment is most strongly indicated for those with:



  • Systemic symptoms (eg, weight loss, inanition, persistent fever).
  • Persistently positive sputum AFB.
  • Cavitary lung disease at presentation.
  • Progressive pulmonary disease (eg, increasing bronchiectasis, new nodules in multiple lung segments, declining PFT).
  • Underlying high-risk conditions (eg, emphysema, immunodeficiency).

Antibiotic therapy



Multidrug antibiotic therapy is the first line of treatment.



  • Pulmonary NTM is treated with macrolide (azithromycin or clarithromycin) plus ethambutol plus rifampin (or rifabutin) for at least 12 months beyond sputum culture conversion back to negative.  Parenteral therapy (eg, intravenous amikacin or streptomycin) may be added for severe cavitary disease.
  • DMAC (eg, in a patient with HIV) is treated with a similar macrolide-based antibiotic regimen (Â± rifabutin), and therapy is continued until immune reconstitution, typically defined as CD4 >100/mm3 for â‰¥6 months on ART.  As with TB, immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome may occur after ART initiation; this is marked by paradoxic worsening due to increased T-cell reactivity against MAC.  It is usually managed with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or corticosteroids, while continuing both ART and antibiotics.


Macrolides commonly cause gastrointestinal upset and may prolong the QT interval.  Rifamycins can lead to hepatotoxicity, cytopenias, and significant drug-drug interactions (eg, CYP450 inducer).  Ethambutol may cause optic neuritis (eg, loss of red-green discrimination) and peripheral neuropathy.  Monitoring includes periodic blood counts, liver and renal function tests, vision screening, and baseline audiometry (if aminoglycosides are used).  Adherence is limited (eg, only ~60% of patients complete the full course) due to adverse effects, pill burden, and duration.  With good adherence, microbiologic cure is achieved approximately 70% of the time.



Treatment of M abscessus and M fortuitum involves even more extensive antibiotics, often â‰¥4 classes (eg, macrolides, aminoglycosides, carbapenems, tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones); these antibiotic classes often require rotation based on susceptibility.  M abscessus is particularly refractory.  It has intrinsic and inducible drug resistance (eg, efflux pumps).  The goal is frequently disease suppression rather than cure.  Surgery (eg, lung resection, debridement) is often necessary for localized or refractory infections.

Source control surgery



Surgery may be necessary in select cases.



  • For pulmonary NTM, resection (eg, lobectomy, segmentectomy) may be required for refractory localized infection, severe cavitation, or hemoptysis.
  • For extrapulmonary NTM, source control includes debridement of skin and soft tissue infections, removal of infected prosthetic material, and resection of abscesses.  Resection is particularly important for M abscessus and other rapid growers, which are highly drug-resistant.


Prolonged multidrug antibiotic therapy is still necessary before and after surgery to reduce organism burden and prevent relapse.

Summary



Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) are environmental acid-fast bacilli, with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) being the most clinically widespread.  Transmission occurs through inhalation (most common), ingestion, or direct inoculation.  Pulmonary NTM present in either a nodular/bronchiectatic pattern or a fibrocavitary disease resembling reactivation tuberculosis.  Disease mostly develops in susceptible hosts with structural lung disease or cellular immunodeficiency but can also affect thin, elderly women without other clear risk factors (Lady Windermere syndrome).  Disseminated MAC is most common in advanced HIV and involves marked constitutional symptoms, abdominal lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and cytopenias.  Other species cause distinct syndromes such as cervical lymphadenitis (MAC), skin and soft tissue infections (Mycobacterium marinum, Mycobacterium abscessus), or nosocomial device infections.  Diagnosis requires imaging abnormalities and microbiologic confirmation to distinguish true disease from colonization.  Management is individualized:  Stable, asymptomatic cases may be observed, but progressive or symptomatic disease warrants prolonged multidrug antibiotic therapy, typically with a macrolide, rifamycin, and ethambutol.  Treatment is challenging due to frequent medication adverse effects.  Surgery can provide source control for localized or refractory disease but must always be combined with antibiotics.
